item.title: SEBI cautions against investing in digital gold
item.description: Digital gold is unregulated. A timely reminder from SEBI. Most people don‚Äôt realize that nobody regulates digital gold, and if something were to happen to the platforms or companies selling it, there‚Äôs not much you can do. It‚Äôs also a subpar way to get exposure to gold. You pay 3% GST the moment you buy. Then there are spreads of another 2‚Äì3%, which means as soon as you purchase digital gold, you‚Äôre already down about 6%, and that‚Äôs before even factoring in regulatory risk.

item.title: Robinhood makes $150 million a year just from instant withdrawal fee
item.description: I just discovered that Robinhood will generate approximately $150 million (~‚Çπ1,300 crores) in revenue from the fees it charges for processing instant client withdrawals. Their cost to process these is around $35‚Äì40 million, which means a clean $100 million to the bottom line, and that‚Äôs just from instant withdrawals. üò¨ As an Indian startup with some scale, founders dream of generating revenue like this from non-core products. Hence the rush to introduce everything: loans, insurance, payments, and other financial services.

item.title: Discussion with Adnan from Devils Circuit on fitness and health
item.description: Of everyone I‚Äôve met, Adnan has to be one of the most passionate advocates for fitness and getting Indians to participate in active sports. His company, Devils Circuit, has faced its fair share of obstacles and ups and downs ‚Äî but the mission remains strong: inspiring Indians to take a greater interest in their health and fitness. And my gut tells me, the time when we truly start caring more about our health is coming soon.

item.title: Zerodha LIQUIDCASE grows to ‚Çπ6,000 crore AUM in under two years
item.description: Zerodha LIQUIDCASE is India’s first liquid ETF with a growth NAV, and we launched it in January 2024. In just under two years, it’s incredible that the AUM has reached almost ‚Çπ6,000 crores. All of this growth is organic, from traders and investors discovering the ETF and investing in it. We haven’t really spoken about it much, and you can’t pay commissions on an ETF anyway. The innovation here was simple: no dividends, because they were tax-inefficient and a pain to redeem and track.

item.title: How India‚Äôs tax structure rewards growth over profits
item.description: If you take money out of a business as dividends, the effective tax rate is 52% (25% corporate tax + 35.5% on personal income). Through capital gains, it‚Äôs just 14.95% (with cess). Why does this matter? Here‚Äôs what you should know if you invest in IPOs. If you‚Äôre an investor (especially a VC), the math is simple: reduce corporate tax by showing minimal profits or losses. Spend (Burn) on acquiring users, build a growth narrative, and then sell shares at a higher valuation while paying much lower tax.

item.title: Didn‚Äôt expect our support for FFmpeg to get this much love
item.description: The amount of love this has gotten is quite crazy. I was just asking K, ‘How does it make sense that there are tech companies worth billions and trillions of dollars who use these pieces of open source software without which they could not exist, and yet are unwilling to fund them?’ We‚Äôve been funding open source projects from ~2018 on and off before setting up FLOSS/fund in 2024. We run on open source, so supporting is a no-brainer.

item.title: The one thing I wish I‚Äôd done differently after my stroke
item.description: If there‚Äôs one thing I wish I had done differently when I was hit by a stroke last January, it would be to go to the hospital immediately, within the Golden Hour (<4.5 hours), instead of thinking I could just sleep it off. This ‚Äúnothing will happen to me‚Äù attitude is common, especially among those under 50. But the truth is, strokes are rising sharply, up to nearly 30% of all strokes in the last few years, among 30 to 50-year-olds.

item.title: AMA with Zerodha's core team
item.description: A bunch of you asked us questions about our revenues, regulations, international investing, AI, and more. Nikhil, Kailash, Karthik Rangappa, Venu, and I answered a lot of those questions in this AMA. Since there were several questions about US investing: we didn’t offer it until now because the regulations were unclear, but now there’s clarity. In May, SEBI and IFSCA allowed brokers to operate in GIFT City, and in June, the exchanges allowed brokers to offer third-party products.

item.title: Indian VC ecosystem has changed quite a bit in 15 years
item.description: The Indian VC ecosystem has changed quite a bit in 15 years. When we started Zerodha in 2010, “VC” was an exotic term, and there was barely any startup activity. The most popular VCs were dads, uncles and aunts. Starting around 2010, we began seeing interest driven by India’s “opportunity size.” India’s population has done more to attract VC money than anything else üòõ “India has 120 crore people, and even if 1% buy X”

item.title: 1929 by Andrew Ross Sorkin is a must-read for anyone in the markets
item.description: 1929 by Andrew Ross Sorkin is a must-read for anyone in the markets‚Äîstocks, commodities, or crypto. He quotes US President Hoover (1929): ‚ÄúThe only problem with capitalism is capitalists. They‚Äôre too damn greedy.‚Äù Every crash, 1907, 1929, 1987, 2001 (Dotcom), 2008 (GFC), and so many more, follows the same script. Greed drives markets higher, inflating bubbles that draw in even those who don‚Äôt understand the risks. As euphoria builds, leverage accumulates quietly somewhere in the system: loans, margins, complex derivatives.

item.title: One year of the Zerodha FLOSS fund
item.description: We started FLOSS/fund in 2024 to give up to $1 million annually to support the development of FOSS (free and open-source) projects globally. Here’s what K said in a post reflecting on the past year, making the case for the Indian government also to fund FOSS for strategic tech sovereignty: “Actually, no amount of material resources can enable governments to develop, nurture, and sustain complex, high-quality FOSS projects themselves in the way a community of passionate maintainers can.

item.title: Cybersecurity is as human as it is technical
item.description: So, my personal Twitter account was compromised yesterday because I fell for a phishing e-mail early in the morning while at home when browsing on my personal device. A momentary lapse in attention. The e-mail got through all spam and phishing filters. I clicked on the ‘Change Your Password’ link and entered the password. The attackers gained access to a single login session, using it to tweet a few scammy cryptocurrency links.

item.title: The love we get for all the content is crazy
item.description: The love we get for all the content on Varsity, Markets by Zerodha etc. is crazy. üòÄWhat we’ve done from day 1 is focus on sharing quality insights rather than chasing engagement, pointless optimizations, and gimmicks. The trust we’ve built over almost a decade is a direct result of that‚Äîpeople reading and watching us and then sharing it with their friends and family.

item.title: Open source for tech sovereignty
item.description: Tech sovereignty and self-sufficiency are national conversations now, the world over. Free and open-source software (FOSS) enables just that‚Äîtech sovereignty and, at the same time, mutually assured global collaboration and innovation. IndiaAI Mission’s recent push for sovereign open-source LLMs is a great example for this. Without FOSS, there would be no Zerodha or the global digital ecosystem as we know it today. Here’s an article by K (Kailash) on the topic from 2021 that’s still relevant now.

item.title: Financial inclusion needs more than just digital access
item.description: The entire Indian financial services industry, including Zerodha, has been a massive beneficiary of the ease of digital onboarding via Aadhaar e-Sign, eKYC, etc. It has been a big reason for the increase in financial inclusion among Tier 2 and 3 cities and rural parts of the country; people who had not previously interacted with the formal financial system. While many of us take the benefits of these digital systems for granted, being in a city like Bengaluru (and a position of privilege), I was surprised by the extent of challenges with OTP verification and the physical/biometric side of these systems until I read articles like these in The Times of India and elsewhere.

item.title: India‚Äôs $3 trillion in idle gold needs smarter financialization.
item.description: Indian households hold ~$3 trillion in gold (World Gold Council estimate), sitting idle in lockers. Meanwhile, equity investments fund companies that need capital to grow. We need better ways to financialize this gold beyond just gold loans.

item.title: RBI move could make LAS more popular
item.description: One good change from RBI yesterday: banks can now lend up to ‚Çπ1 crore against shares, up from the earlier ‚Çπ20 lakhs. Hopefully, this makes loan against securities (LAS) more popular. It‚Äôs ridiculous how many people holding stocks continue taking personal loans or using credit cards at much higher rates‚Äîcredit cards can go up to 40%+. Even at Zerodha Capital, we see this constantly. People just aren‚Äôt aware they can replace high-interest debt with LAS, which is one reason our book is still only ‚Çπ450 crores.

item.title: Why short-term growth is the wrong metric
item.description: On the question of what would we do if weekly options were removed, I suppose we’ll see another hit to our revenues in the short-term. Having said that, when you’re building a business for the long term, focusing on quarterly or even annual growth is a poor metric. The more you focus on them, the higher the odds that you’ll do things that are bad for your customers.
